brief_summary.textblock:
This fracture of the distal tibia occurs in 1 to 4 year-old-children. The child usually
      presents with an acute onset of limp or refusal to bear weight on one leg. Toddlers and
      young children may present with guarding, but may not have swelling or noticeable deformity.

      Radiologic signs can be subtle too. In some cases initial radiographs is negative and
      fractures are diagnosed on follow-up studies by periosteal reaction.

      However, timely diagnosis is important, because it obviates the need for investigations to
      archive adequate treatment as well as to prevent unnecessary immobilization. The value of
      sonographic diagnosis of toddler's fracture has been demonstrated. In children it is of
      particular value as it is comfortable and does not involve the use of ionizing radiation.

      The aim of the present study is to investigate the reliability and accuracy of sonography in
      the diagnostic workup of the toddler's fracture.

clinical_study.brief_title: Value of Sonographic Diagnosis of Toddler's Fracture of the Tibia

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          1. Informed consent

          2. Suspicion of Toddlers fractures

        Exclusion Criteria:

        1. Major delay in treatment

study_pop.textblock: Children with suspicion of Toddlers fractures.

primary_outcome.description: Comparison of sensitivity and specitivity of sonography and x-ray

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: US does not cause more discomfort than x-ray

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Prospective
